title: 51 Inmates Refuse To Be Locked In Cells At State’s Maximum Security Prison
text:
51 Inmates Refuse To Be Locked In Cells At State’s Maximum Security Prison January 9, 2017 9:00 PM Filed Under: Souza Baranowski Correctional Center 
SHIRLEY (CBS) – Corrections officers have regains control of a housing unit at the Souza-Baranowski Correctional Facility in Shirley after dozens of inmates refused to be locked in their cells Monday afternoon. 
The Department of Corrections says 51 inmates in the P-1 Housing Unit at the maximum security prison were involved in the incident. 
The disturbance started at about 3:50 p.m. when there was fight between two inmates in the unit. 
While corrections officers were attempting to secure the inmates in their cells, another fight broke out. After that fight, the remaining inmates refused to return to their cells and corrections officers were pulled from the unit. 
After the officers left, the inmates began destroying the unit. Souza Baranowski prison cell (WBZ-TV) 
According to the Department of Corrections, sprinkler heads were broken off, camera systems and the computer system were destroyed, and inmates used fire extinguishers and other makeshift weapons to destroy furniture and windows. 
At approximately 7:00 pm, officers from the Special Operations Unit used a chemical agent to gain control of the inmates. 
Numerous State Police units were sent to the prison to assist but it is unclear if they entered the prison. COs often deal w/ inmates refusing lock-in. This large # unusual. Fortunately tactical team doesn't have to get any employees OUT. #WBZ 
— Juli McDonald (@julimcdonald) January 9, 2017 
Each inmate was searched and there were no serious injuries reported. 
The inmates involved will face disciplinary sanctions and criminal charges could be filed. 
The prison remains locked down while the situation is investigated. 
Convicted killer Aaron Hernandez is an inmate at the prison, but a source tells WBZ he is not in the unit where the incident occurred.
